newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Kiwi founder seeks protective airline laws.
newsitem.headline: Kiwi founder seeks protective airline laws.

text.p: The founder of defunct New Zealand airline Kiwi International, Ewan Wilson, said on Monday he was seeking government legislation to protect start-up carriers in niche markets.

He said as an example, the legislation could protect a carrier which wanted to fly between Wagga Wagga in south-eastern New South Wales and Invercargill on the southern tip of New Zealand's south island.
"We would in fact reduce the barriers of entry by making it possible for new start-up carriers with a less amount of capital to pioneer new routes," Wilson told an aviation conference.
Wilson said the introduction of this legislation would prompt him to try again with the formation of a second Kiwi International airline.
"I have spoken to a member of parliament and we've had a discussion and we'll continue to have discussions," he said.
"I think once December 10 comes along and we have a coalition government then we'll be able to speed up that process."
New Zealand Labour Party deputy leader Michael Cullen said earlier this month he expected the next NZ government to be formed by December 10.
New Zealand First Party leader Winston Peters, who holds the balance of power, also said he expected the new government to be formed within the next few weeks.
Wilson's Hamilton-based airline went into liquidation on September 10 with liquidators saying that its creditors were unlikely to recover anything.
Wilson has previously attributed the collapse to severe competition, mechanical faults and flight disruptions from the eruption of Mount Ruapehu in the North Island of New Zealand.
